title: 2008 Viva World Cup
text:
The 2008 VIVA World Cup was the second <a href="VIVA%20World%20Cup">VIVA World Cup</a>, an international tournament for <a href="Association%20football">football</a>, that took place in July 2008. The winners were <a href="Padania%20national%20football%20team">Padania</a>, who took home the <a href="Nelson%20Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a> Trophy. The tournament was organised by the <a href="Nouvelle%20F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration-Board">Nouvelle Fédération-Board</a>.
The defending champions and hosts were <a href="S%C3%A1pmi%20national%20football%20team">Sápmi</a>. The competition, organized by the <a href="Sami%20people">Sami people</a>, took place from 7 to 13 July, in <a href="G%C3%A4llivare">Gällivare</a>, <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a>.
Qualification.
Due to the inaugural status of this tournament, applicants were admitted to the tournament without a qualification process. As an untested tournament the scheduling doesn't meet the organizational capacity of a billion dollar organization like <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a>.

Venues.
As a small tournament, like its European counterpart in <a href="Europeada%202008">Europeada 2008</a>, this VIVA World Cup was not expected to bring in the numbers and financial support of <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202008">UEFA Euro 2008</a> earlier this summer; the <a href="stadium">stadia</a> venues are thus rather small.

Overview.
<a href="Padania">Padania</a> became the 2008 VIVA World Cup champions beating Arameans Suryoye in the final 2–0. The hosts Sapmi, after coming 4th in the group stage, ended by as a lucky 3rd after winning the last edition. The <a href="Arameans%20Suryoye">Arameans Suryoye</a> team were the surprise of the tournament qualifying for the final at their first attempt. <a href="Iraqi%20Kurdistan">Iraqi Kurdistan</a>, also debuting, finished 3rd in the group stage but lost in the 4th place play off to Sapmi. To round of the places, in a distant last position, having lost all of their group games, was <a href="Provence">Provence</a>, a region of France.
In the inaugural women's tournament the hosts Sapmi came through after an aggregate 16–1 thrashing of Iraqi Kurdistan.
